Introduction

Erysipelas is a rapidly spreading skin infection affecting the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics.  It is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and classically manifests as tender, warm, well-demarcated erythema of the face or lower extremities.

Pathogenesis



Erysipelas is a rapidly spreading skin infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatic system that most commonly occurs in young children and older adults.  Infection typically develops in an area of skin disruption (eg, abrasion, insect bite) and is most commonly caused by S pyogenes, or group A Streptococcus (GAS).  Less commonly, other beta-hemolytic streptococci (eg, groups C or G streptococci) can cause disease.



The proliferation of S pyogenes with subsequent spread to the superficial lymphatic system leads to immune system activation, causing local erythema, edema, and warmth as well as systemic manifestations of fever and chills.

Risk factors



Risk factors for the development of erysipelas include the following:



  • Skin barrier disruption, such as local trauma (eg, surgical wounds, insect bites, diabetic foot ulcers) and underlying dermatologic conditions (eg, eczema)
  • Impaired lymphatic drainage, as in patients with lymphedema (eg, postmastectomy)
  • Immunocompromising conditions, including HIV infection, malignancy, and diabetes mellitus

Clinical presentation



Systemic symptoms of erysipelas (eg, fever, chills, malaise, headache) develop acutely, typically hours before cutaneous findings.  Skin manifestations include a warm, tender, erythematous rash notable for raised, sharply demarcated borders (

image 1
).  The affected area may appear shiny and tense due to edema, which may also result in a peau d'orange (orange-peel) texture from dimpling of the skin around involved hair follicles.  Localized lymphadenopathy is common.



Typical affected areas include the lower extremities and face (eg, malar area); involvement of the external ear is particularly suggestive of erysipelas as this skin lacks a lower dermis, making a deeper skin infection unlikely.

Differential diagnosis



  • Cellulitis with or without abscess (

    ):  This skin infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat is usually caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococcus or Staphylococcus aureus (
    figure 1
    ).  Infections begin in areas of skin disruption, but patients develop a slowly spreading rash (typically with fluctuance if abscess is present) that is warm, tender, and erythematous with flat, indistinct borders (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Necrotizing fasciitis (
    image 2
    ):  This rapidly spreading infection classically presents with poorly demarcated erythema and pain out of proportion to examination findings.  Skin breakdown with crepitus, bullae, and ecchymoses may be seen.
  • Impetigo (
    image 3
    ):  Pustules and honey-colored crusting are characteristic of impetigo, a superficial bacterial infection that is not associated with systemic symptoms (eg, fever).
  • Erythema migrans (
    image 4
    ):  Early localized Lyme disease manifests with erythema migrans, a nontender rash with a bull's-eye appearance and central clearing.
  • Contact dermatitis (
    image 5
    ):  Well-demarcated erythema may occur in contact dermatitis.  Pruritis is common, and vesiculobullous lesions may be present.  In addition, systemic symptoms are not typical, and history often reveals an exposure history to an irritant or allergen.
  • Herpes zoster (shingles) (
    image 6
    ):  This reactivation of latent varicella zoster virus presents with painful, erythematous papules in a dermatomal distribution that subsequently become vesicles and crust over.

Diagnosis



Erysipelas is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on the acute onset of systemic symptoms with a raised, well-demarcated, erythematous skin lesion (typically on the face or lower extremities).



Laboratory evaluation (eg, complete blood count, inflammatory markers, blood culture) is typically reserved for patients with extensive rash, systemic toxicity, or underlying comorbidities (eg, diabetes mellitus).  Imaging (eg, CT, MRI) is also unnecessary unless deep tissue involvement is suspected.

Management



Treatment of erysipelas targets beta-hemolytic Streptococcus, and first-line therapy is penicillin (eg, penicillin V, amoxicillin).



For patients with extensive skin involvement, systemic toxicity (eg, hypotension), or immunocompromising conditions (eg, neutropenia), hospitalization with intravenous therapy (eg, ceftriaxone) is indicated.  Treatment can be narrowed (eg, penicillin G) if cultures confirm GAS.

Prognosis and complications



With appropriate therapy, symptoms of erysipelas typically improve within 2-3 days.  Without treatment, deeper infection of skin and soft tissue may occur, including cellulitis and abscess, as well as hematogenous spread causing bacteremia and sepsis.  Rarely, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis can develop 2-4 weeks after infection.



Recurrence of erysipelas is common, particularly in patients with lymphedema.

Summary



Erysipelas, most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, presents with fever and acute, rapidly spreading erythema with well-demarcated, raised borders.  First-line treatment is penicillin.  Untreated erysipelas can lead to abscess formation, bacteremia, and sepsis.
